required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Computerized Single-Session Interventions for Indian Adolescents
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluating the Acceptability and Efficacy of Computerized Single-Session Interventions for Indian Adolescents

brief_summary.textblock: The overall aim of this project is to understand if single-session interventions are acceptable, culturally appropriate, and effective for Indian adolescents. The investigators will be examining the effects of three interventions on the well-being and mental health of adolescents. The investigators hypothesize that at least one of the three interventions will yield statistically significant improvements in wellbeing and mental health relative to a study skills control condition.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in The Warwick-Edinburgh Mental Wellbeing Scale
primary_outcome.description: Well-being questionnaire. Total score ranges from 14 to 70. Higher values indicate a better outcome.

Questionnaire measuring the appropriateness of an intervention. Appropriateness refers to the perceived fit or relevance of an intervention. The total score ranges from 4 to 20. Higher scores indicate a better outcome.

secondary_outcome.description: Depression Questionnaire. The total score ranges from 0 to 27. Lower scores indicate a better outcome.
Anxiety Questionnaire. The total score ranges from 0 to 21. Lower scores indicate a better outcome.

secondary_outcome.measure: The EPOCH Measure of Adolescent Well-being
secondary_outcome.description: Questionnaire with five subscales measuring engagement, perseverance, optimism, connectedness, and happiness. Each subscale score ranges from 4 to 20. Higher scores indicate a better outcome. The happiness and optimism subscales will be used as secondary outcomes for this trial. A total score is not computed.

Questionnaire measuring the acceptability of an intervention. Acceptability refers to the perception that a given treatment is agreeable or satisfactory. The total score ranges from 4 to 20. Higher scores indicate a better outcome.

Questionnaire measuring the feasibility of an intervention. Feasibility refers to the degree to which a treatment can be successfully implemented in a given setting. The total score ranges from 4 to 20. Higher scores indicate a better outcome.
Questionnaire measuring perceived stress. The total score ranges from 0 to 16. Lower scores indicate a better outcome.

intervention.description: Reading and writing activities designed to instill the belief that people can change.
Reading and writing activities designed to practice noticing and appreciating good things in life.
Reading and writing activities designed to identify and schedule positive activities.
Reading and writing activities designed to learn evidence-based study strategies.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Attending a participating secondary school
- Age 12 to 18
- Literate in English
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unable to provide informed consent

reference.citation: Schleider J, Weisz J. A single-session growth mindset intervention for adolescent anxiety and depression: 9-month outcomes of a randomized trial. J Child Psychol Psychiatry. 2018 Feb;59(2):160-170. doi: 10.1111/jcpp.12811. Epub 2017 Sep 18.
Seligman ME, Steen TA, Park N, Peterson C. Positive psychology progress: empirical validation of interventions. Am Psychol. 2005 Jul-Aug;60(5):410-21.
Emmons RA, McCullough ME. Counting blessings versus burdens: an experimental investigation of gratitude and subjective well-being in daily life. J Pers Soc Psychol. 2003 Feb;84(2):377-89.
Chorpita BF, Becker KD, Daleiden EL. Understanding the common elements of evidence-based practice: misconceptions and clinical examples. J Am Acad Child Adolesc Psychiatry. 2007 May;46(5):647-52.
